title: John Wick female spin off: Are we really ready?
text:
Marvel is tackling spin-offs differently to John Wick

We want to believe we are, but history tells us we’re still not ready for a female-led John Wick, or any other female-led spin-off, to be honest.

And it sucks.

Before you grab the pitchforks and come for me, torches blazing, I’m all for female-led flicks. It shouldn’t be a question – it should be happening.

But judging from past spin-offs led by women that basically caused the world to implode – oh hey, Ghostbusters, didn’t see you there – it makes me question whether the world is really ready to embrace a female-led spin-off retelling a story already established by a man.

I support these stories being created, but I find a problem in the fact it always seems to be a re-telling of a previously male-fronted plot, rather than something new.

Will Ballerina compare to John Wick? (Picture: Rex Features)

Last week it was confirmed Keanu Reeves was acting as executive producer on a John Wick female-spin off, and I so want it to work.

Advertisement

Advertisement

With the success of John Wick 3 earning $323 million (£292 million) worldwide, Lionsgate has decided to move forward on the movie, dubbed Ballerina, that will centre on a female assassin.

Female assassins are awesome – may I bring your attention to Charlize Theron in Atomic Blonde – but off the back of John Wick I can only assume the box office takings will be compared, the action will be scrutinised and the character will be analysed alongside Keanu’s titular lead star.

It’s not a good start when Ballerina is focusing on an assassin hell-bent on vengeance. Exactly the same trope rolled out for John Wick.

Perhaps the question shouldn’t be ‘are the fans ready for all-female spin-offs’, it’s ‘are film companies ready to put their money on the line and take some chances on fresh content that riffs on past stories, instead of re-doing them’.

Fresh stories fronted by women will work, not re-doing what has been done (Picture: Rex Features)

You’ve got to risk it to get the biscuit and by giving women a story but making it the same plot trivialises the whole meaning. It’s like the women are being thrown a bone by getting to take on characters previously helmed by men.

Why can’t we ditch the ‘all-female/female-led spinoffs’ and create fresh content, totally separate from what had come before? Without the legacy of the wildly-popular original hanging over it for diehard fans to compare it to.

If Ballerina does flop, people will say it’s all because it’s got a female lead, as opposed to simply not having Keanu Reeves. In this, Hollywood bosses will be even more reluctant to take chances on fresh female-led content.

People just weren’t a fan of this remake (Picture: Rex Features)

From past experience, it’s become clear the fanbase of these films and franchises aren’t welcoming of their beloved tales being redone with women.

Advertisement

Advertisement

The fandom was seething when four women – Kate McKinnon, Melissa McCarthy, Leslie Jones and Kristen Wiig – took on the beloved franchise of Ghostbusters in a pretty much identical film with the genders flipped in 2016.

And they voted at the box office, with the reboot taking $229million (£181million), still a tidy figure for any film, but with it prepped to be a mighty Sony blockbuster it was seen as a loss in the eyes of critics.

What could have been a really awesome story was sullied by the fact it was clearly trying to capitalise on the success of the OG films, and in turn it didn’t measure up in the eyes of the audience.

Oceans 8 worked because it was different (Picture: Warner Bros. Entertainment Inc)

I’m sure there are many who simply didn’t like the fact girls were allowed in the Ghostbusters clubhouse, but to me it was almost a disservice to the females leading these spin-offs when they’re just picking up what the dudes did before.

Had a fresh film, away from the history of the original, been created I hazard a guess the vitriol and venom wouldn’t have been so harsh.

Paint me pessimistic but I fear the audiences aren’t going to respond to their favourite franchises being spun-off so unimaginatively. We need to do better for the fans AND for the stories and women being represented.

We’ve seen this can work – think Oceans 8. This was no ‘spin-off’ or ‘reboot’, it was a fresh sequel that carried on from the original Oceans films that were fronted by males.

Advertisement

And it grossed nearly $300million (£237million), proving powerful women can continue the story started by a guy, and that’s the difference. Keep the story going, move it on, just don’t re-do it because you’re too lazy to think of a brilliant new tale for the women to tell.

Brie Larson has revealed that she and her fellow female MCU stars have pitched the idea of an all-women Marvel film to boss Kevin Feige.

When it comes to Marvel, the female characters rising to the top in a potential film is something I feel will rally the troops. It’s not copying past films, it’s creating something new.

Captain Marvel, Scarlet Witch, Shuri, Valkyrie, Mantis, Gamora, Okoye, Nebula, Hope Van Dyne and Pepper Potts kicking butt? It’ll totally work – because these characters weren’t created as a trivial attempt at diversity. Same with Black Widow. That spin-off will work because it’s not trying to re-do a past story.

Sure you could argue that we’ll only make positive changes if we simply start somewhere, and by me sitting here being all Debbie downer over female spin-offs I’m part of the problem.

All I want is for producers to not feel they’re doing us a favour by giving us a female-led film that’s all same same but different gender.

We can totally handle a fresh story. Promise.
